Can you rewrite this to make it more explicit that glance-api actually needs to be running in standalone mode? Running it under mod_wsgi wouldn't work either according to the discussion in IRC.

Yes, this is correct.
Will change it, but still if someone sets this to True and ran tempest then it will fail with what I have commented in the replies.

Kindly let me know what is going wrong in this scenario as I am out of ideas now.

The problem is that WSGI_MODE=uwsgi, which means we use the import mechanism, but the image never gets out of 'uploading' state because the task doesn't run. I think we need to make this only do import if both the flag is true AND WSGI_MODE!=uwsgi. See my revision patch on top of this one.
Not being able to use the cloud.yaml config is a show stopper for me, can that functionality be added to glanceclient? Otherwise I'd strongly vote to only use OSC functionality.

> This seems like a great opportunity to work together and improve
 > everyone's experience.

I'm trying to fix up as much glance and devstack stuff as I can so that I can test my nova feature in support of this goal :)

 > https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737608/
 > 
 > I just wrote a patch to use the already-existing support for image
 > upload in sdk with the image creation workflow. Assuming this works
 > (which, you know - let's assume there's a bug - and also probably
 > will need to update an existing unittest and add another unittest
 > to we've covering both sides) it will, upon being released,
 > immediately make osc use the interop image workflow if it finds it.

It's not clear to me that what you're saying is the same as image-create-via-import, but if so, then ... great.

 > It seems like having a devstack config both with and without uwsgi
 > for sdk's functional tests should cover both with and without image
 > upload, yes?

Not sure about that. For glanceclient, they're two different mechanisms. The regular way (which is equivalent to the osc way) doesn't trigger the import mechanism at all. The import way (line below) does trigger it, but will cause the image to never go into active state if glance is running as a uwsgi app.

So assuming you know more about the parity among those operations than I do, then ... great, I don't care how we tickle it, just that we do. This has been a kinda critical feature for glance for a while now that we've not been testing in CI, which is a problem, IMHO.

I'd also like an answer from whoever to my question about devstack requiring osc going forward. We have things in nova you can't do with osc, and we just had a PTG where support for requiring new features be added to osc/sdk before they can be landed in nova was pretty chilly. I'm definitely not in support of devstack being the stick we use to beat people into submission, instead of a tool to help keep test coverage high. From what I can tell, glance's recent dearth of real test coverage on their new features has come from not being able to meet devstack's demands with their paltry staffing (see the just recently merged g-reg removal, years after a stub was put into glance to be able to remove it without disturbing devstack). I'd much rather have devstack be inconsistent in client usage (a reflection of the current reality, btw) than projects like glance just not even trying to test new features that require things like this.

Just to be clear, you would rather us not be able to test import image conversion (which has been in glance untested for several cycles) and Nova's use of that feature (which I just implemented and am trying to use now) until osc gains support for this mechanism? I have a hard time understanding that tradeoff, unless there is some actual technical reason. This does work in my testing here, so what is the actual hard dep on cloud.yaml? FWIW, people using this in the wild are doing it with glanceclient, just like many things in nova that aren't supported in OSC have to be done with novaclient today.

This seems like a great opportunity to work together and improve everyone's experience.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737608/

I just wrote a patch to use the already-existing support for image upload in sdk with the image creation workflow. Assuming this works (which, you know - let's assume there's a bug - and also probably will need to update an existing unittest and add another unittest to we've covering both sides) it will, upon being released, immediately make osc use the interop image workflow if it finds it.

I'll follow up with a patch add plumb through support for the --url import flag, but for now that patch should take care of it.

It seems like having a devstack config both with and without uwsgi for sdk's functional tests should cover both with and without image upload, yes?

Anyway - I don't see any reason we can't get that patch finished up, landed and released in the next day ... at which point it'll mean we will have added support to sdk, zuul, openstackclient, ansible and salt.
Just being curious: Is there a technical reason for this or is this just a bug in glance that prevents this?

IIUC neutron has created a neutron-rpc service to be handling such things when neutron-server is running under uwsgi.

But indeed I would like to consider devstack not only a testing tool, but also a blueprint for how to deploy OpenStack in the real world, so I'm all for making stuff more realistic.

Yeah, glance is unable to spawn background threads that run to completion when used under uwsgi. Nova has the same problem, which prevents checking things like rabbit heartbeats, which we've had to squelch since the move to uwsgi.

Since things like import format conversion, metadata tagging, and import copy-to-store all require background threads in the glance-api worker, these features will never work under uwsgi.

TBH, my next step after getting all this stuff working and tested with WSGI_MODE=mod_wsgi, was going to be to suggest a way to make glance-api never run under uwsgi, since it pretty much can't function normally at all in that way. At RedHat, we don't run it under uwsgi in the product that way, and testing it like that makes this not very realistic.

Yep, and Nova has workers over RPC to handle such things (other than what can't be delegated like the heartbeat checks). Since glance needs to stream the image it's working on, it's kinda fundamentally not able to delegate long-running tasks like this, as it wouldn't be reasonable to either stream a multi-GiB image over RPC, nor require a shared highly-available filesystem or similar. Obviously addressing this would be a fundamental architectural change to Glance, which just isn't feasible, especially given they are already struggling to keep up with maintenance.

let's not echo "unable to use import..." if import itself is not requested.

something like below.

    if [[ "$GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW" == "True" ]]; then
        if [[ $WSGI_MODE" != "uwsgi" ]]; then
            echo "*** Using glance import workflow ***"
            useimport="--import"
        else 
           echo "*** Glance import workflow requested but unable to use because WSGI_MODE=uwsgi! ***"
        fi
    fi

lib/tempest.message:
Can you please add a retry counter with a limit? Waiting forever without a timeout when somethings gets stuck should be avoided.

I'm also unsure whether this wait should actually happen here or directly after the image upload in lib/glance, which would also protect other possible consumers.

Yep, understand, no argument about a timeout. I put this here because the image was _never_ going into active state and the below search for active images wasn't showing us useful info. I think that a specific check that something went to active is a good idea, which is why I left it here, but am happy to make it timeout.

TBH, I'm not super concerned about the grenade case as I don't think there's any reason to need to configure a grenade job to use the import workflow in the short term (we don't test ceph deployments with grenade currently, AFAIK). In reality, if things don't break, a cirros image should upload and convert very fast and not ever even need us to wait here.

But, if you would rather me put the wait loop near image upload for the future, then that's fine.

> Waiting here makes the job take less time because we overlap the
 > import operation with more stack setup. Only here does it matter,
 > and if you were to not enable tempest, it wouldn't matter if it
 > didn't finish by the time devstack ended.

What about e.g. grenade? That will run devstack to install the "old" side and then start the upgrade procedure. What will happen to the image if glance api is restarted halfway?

 > Yes, I can add a limit. This was to catch an error so we could see
 > it and I relied on the job timeout to eventually kill it.

If we can call this failed after like 5 minutes, we don't need to wait two more hours. Also devstack isn't only used for jobs but also by users to deploy a developing environment.

Waiting here makes the job take less time because we overlap the import operation with more stack setup. Only here does it matter, and if you were to not enable tempest, it wouldn't matter if it didn't finish by the time devstack ended.

Yes, I can add a limit. This was to catch an error so we could see it and I relied on the job timeout to eventually kill it.
Isn't that the wrong way round? You want to wait when the state is still uploading, not end the loop.
yeah, anyways tempest will be using these image while running tests so enough time for image to be in active. but as dan mentioned we can add some wait if it start failing.
Yeah, I said I was just going to delete this and I should have, since we don't hit it in CI anyway. So I'll just remove it and let the below active image search fail.

distributedcloud/dcorch/engine/sync_thre.message:
First, this code is not equivalent to the default implementation of get_resource_id().  If your getattr() returns anything that evaluates to "false" (like the number 0, or an empty string) then your version will try to return resource.id instead.  It's not likely that this would ever happen in this specific usage, but it's an undocumented behaviour change.

Second, the whole reason why a subclass would override the default definition is because the default is not appropriate or not sufficient.  In that case, we would *want* to invoke the subclass definition of get_resource_id().

This doesn't seem like the right solution. If the subclass is overriding the get_resource_id method, and that method isn't working, then shouldn't we fix it? Also, I see another call to get_resource_id in this class - does that call suffer from the same issue?

nova/scheduler/utils.py.message: I guess you need to set this as True also for MIXED policy.

No. 'self.cpu_pinning_requesting' is a fallback action controller. If it is set to True, then the it met the situation that no PCPU available in host, but it is assumed that this is a hot to be upgarded but all host CPU should be PCPUs.
This is not right for 'MIXED' instance, 'MIXED' instance only could be succuesfully created on UPGRADED host, because 'MIXED' instance requires both PCPU and VCPU.

If we check this here, then the check is done at API layer, then the user can get error response from the boot API directly.

doc/source/install/storage-install-rdo.r.message:
Should we have something similar on https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/install/controller-install-rdo.html to open up 8080? Or are we assuming that some other service like haproxy or apache2 or hitch or blahblahblah will be fronting it?

Should we consider publishing some XML so users can run

 firewall-cmd --permanent --new-service-from-file=...

? If so, should it be one file per layer, or all in one?

In the immediate problem environment, RH OSP Director manages so-called "controller" nodes, which host Swift proxy, and "external storage nodes" are the only ones configured without Director. But from the upstream perspective, I think it would be right to mention proxies and rsync too. Unfortunately, adding pre-canned firewalld descriptors is difficult. They are often made to allow traffic from everywhere, and operators only allow traffic from their load balancers. I'm afraid to create insecure-by-default installations.

I changed it to "Kubernetes object file" because the name of "manifest" is a little confusing to the one in VNF Package. According to Kubernetes official document, the file name seems not clearly defined so I use "Kubernetes object file" in this spec.

Hi. For this, I think the best way is that when we create CNF, 
we make a system that it doesn't check VNFD. 

Or, it process internally, first and changed it. 

What do you think?

IMO, it's better to use VNFD for two reasons.
1. CNF with VM-based App
  CNF can be deployed with VM based applications. In the case,
  it's better to allow operators to define CNF and VNF in a
  single VNFD.

2. Single VNF Package for k8s of pre-installed and on VM
  It's simple for operators to deploy CNF with single VNF
  Package for both case of instantiation on pre-installed k8s
  and on k8s inside VM. In this case, we need top-level VNF 
  and lower-level VNFD. For pre-installed k8s, we use an empty 
  VNFD as described in this spec. For CNF inside VM, we can 
  use VNFD as usual specified in my the other spec of "CNF on 
  Kubernetes cluster inside VM".

I meant that when we only create CNF, we don't need to use VNFD checking procedure. That is, if VNFD is not necessary when we create CNF with kubernetes object file , we can change it to pass without  checking VNFD. 

In the future , in the tacker, we can create CNF using VNFD or kubernetes manifest file. 

So, if VNFD is not necessary in your case, using fake VNFD is not good way.  

I'm not sure I understood your intention correctly.
Can we make it more general?
If it is not essential procedure, we doesn't need to mention it here. What do you think?

I put this procedure because we may need to update InstantiatedVnfInfo with k8s objects here. I welcome your feedback. I'm not sure what information should be stored in Tacker DB. I assume to update VnfcResourceInfo in InstantiatedVnfInfo with k8s object files and not to store status of Pods.

Yes. As we use heat-client for OpenStack, we have multiple

ironic/conductor/manager.py.message:
> We have expected that ironic has no assumption on node in
 > maintenance state, I think it's also true for port.
 > 

I concur, but the problem is that if a vif has been bound, we're orphaning data in neutron which results in a user creating a situation for themselves where they are just trying to destroy a node, and then struggle to figure out why things are not working when they try to deploy it again. We see this time and time again with TripleO where for some insane reason, people's default reaction is to delete the node, and often we end up with orphaned vif data.

 > We can remove a port when it's in active & maintenance, but this
 > change will change the behavior, which I think is not appropriate.

It does, and I think this is behavior that we should change otherwise we create a situation where a vif is orpaned and people have to know that is a behavioral issue because they forced their way out of a situation, that the neutron port is still an object. The presence of the vif record at least blocks them temporarily until the vif record has been removed.

 > Another worry is we may have orphaned VIFs during deployment, it
 > prohibits the node from being used. To manually move the node into
 > available pool, we need to remove tenant_vif_port_id, but there is
 > no way to clear it from API since it's in the internal_info. I
 > would prefer to reconstruct the port, compared with hacking into
 > database.

Orphaned vif attachments already prohibit node re-use because neutron doesn't support duplicate mac addresses. We'e landed other code on detachment to reset the mac, but we still need to perform the detachment so it makes sense to force the user to trigger a vif detachment and/or remove the port completely from neutron prior to deleting the node..

That duplication in neutron doesn't have anything to do with needing to manually move or try and edit field contents, because the fundimental problem is the orphaned record in neutron that was never reconciled.
Agreed, that is an issue. Isn't maintenance mode the big hammer though to prevent undeletable nodes?

We have expected that ironic has no assumption on node in maintenance state, I think it's also true for port.

We can remove a port when it's in active & maintenance, but this change will change the behavior, which I think is not appropriate.

Another worry is we may have orphaned VIFs during deployment, it prohibits the node from being used. To manually move the node into available pool, we need to remove tenant_vif_port_id, but there is no way to clear it from API since it's in the internal_info. I would prefer to reconstruct the port, compared with hacking into database.
That would be consistent with node deletion.

I think we discussed in IRC checking the node state, and giving a different 'node is in state transition' message in the cleaning/provisioning/rescuing case. The current message could still be used for instance ports that the user has control over.

I don't know, maybe something has changed in the neutron side (from the context above) that means we must detach VIFs before the node can be re-used, but I think it's the responsibility of users to handle clean up after they put node into maintenance.
As you mentioned, if a node is destroyed, we can still have orphaned VIFs, maybe you are considering a behavior change to prohibit node removal (even in maintenance) when there are VIFs existing?

Might be cleaner to return an empty dict?

We're adding a new driver API here, so apologies for nit-picking, but after it lands, it'll be more difficult to change.

This is returning a dictionary, so get_current_vifs() makes more sense. Except... do we actually have cases where there is more than one (type of) VIF associated with a port?

By 'tag', we mean keyed in the dictionary, right?
get_current_vifs was my preference too. There were reasonable arguments against it.

I was wondering. If there is only max one VIF associated with a port at any given time, then really, if the node isn't in some clean/provision/rescue state, it'll be the tenant VIF? Having said that, it seems like a PITA to code 'if node.state is clean*, deploy*, rescuing*' if the info is already there in the port's internal info.

Would 'get_current_vif_and_use()' which returns a tuple: (vid_id, use) work? where use could be one of None, 'cleaning', 'rescuing', 'provisioning', 'tenant'.

I'm not totally against returning a dictionary; I'm just wondering whether it makes sense. (Where 'makes sense' means the possibility of there being more than one VIF).

We may have multiple items in the dict - during provisioning we could have a tenant port and a provisioning port. At most one should be bound at any time though, and if there is a cleaning/provisioning/rescuing port then that will be the active one rather than the tenant port.

Returning the one active port here makes sense to me. We already have a method to get the VIF ID - we could just add another to return it's type: get_current_vif_(type|tag|something). This could hide the tag name (which has changed in the past) from the caller, and just return cleaning/provisioning/rescusing/inspection/tenant.

ah.... it is coming back to me. So... we need to know if there are any VIFs associated with this port. There could be more than one VIF, but there is at most one VIF that is (currently) bound. 1. if there is a tenant VIF associated with this port we want the user to do a vif-detach (else can't delete port). 2. or if there is some non-tenant VIF then we need to wait for operation to finish before we can delete the port.

The info we need is in this returned dict. Ok, that makes sense. What I'd like is for this method name and description to change, because it doesn't reflect what I think it is meant to. Does the term 'current' mean the VIF that is currently bound to the port? If so, then I would suggest get_vifs(self, task, p_obj). With a description that reflects what is in the dictionary.

Ah. The code in manager.py will check if there is a tenant VIF, so if there is another port that is actually bound, the error msg will be incorrect. So I'd prefer returning a tuple that reflects the active port.

Note that I don't like 'tag' since we were going to add a 'tag' feature (or did we finish adding it?) that is a different 'tag' than this. 'type' is overloaded so why not overload it a bit more :) 'get_current_vif_and_type()' ?

Hmm, now that you mention it, I think the logic in manager.py is correct right now - the tenant VIF is something that the user can do something about (remove the port, delete the instance) so that info should take precedence. Ironic internal ports (cleaning etc) are mostly a case of 'wait for state transition to complete'.

Given all that, simply returning the bound port is insufficient.

I think we should be explicit here about what the dictionary keys are: 'cleaning_vif_port_id', 'provisioning_vif_port_id', 'rescuing_vif_port_id', 'tenant_vif_port_id'. (I guess we don't want to just do 'cleaning', 'provisioning', 'rescuing', 'tenant'? I'm fine with what is there, just thought I'd ask).

kuryr_kubernetes/k8s_client.py.message: How hard will this affect our response on handling events?

I bet not much, if it's just a disconnect due to data timeout, we reconnect immediately (min_backoff=0). If it's a longer outage of Kubernetes API, we start just a normal backoff instead of retrying in a loop.
this is not only log civilizing. Do we want to wait up to 1 min to reconnect? why that much?
That's a valid point. I'd opt for spliting the patch to civilize logging and improving code regarding backoff mechanisms.

It is civilizing logging - without backoff we just try reconnecting several times a second, spamming logs with hundreds of lines when API is down for just a brief period.

Up to a minute seems like a fair number when the API was down for several minutes, I'll try tweaking this.
we don't need the if/raise anymore?

The idea is that way broader range of errors will be caught here, so that first occurrence will only produce a debug LOG. 

I don't want to just reraise exception after specified number of tries as it'll be caught in the upper layer (watcher), logged and retried there. It's better that we just retry with a reasonable backoff of 60 seconds forever - just as K8s services like kubelet do.

I guess, that we need to raise the exception after

  attempt > utils.MAX_ATTEMPTS

Otherwise we would end up in endless loop (or until k8s api start to respond).

kuryr_kubernetes/utils.py.message:
How long do you plan to wait on this exponential thing in k8s client? Why using random? Did you know, that at max attempts, most likely you'll get values expressed in years? Maaaany years. Like millions.

How about using simple equation, like:

    backoff = attempt ** 3

and reduce MAX_ATTEMPTS to 20, which gives you around two hours and thirteen seconds.

My assumption was not to change what was already implemented in exponential_sleep, the algorithm's source is explained there. I expect the random there is to make sure all the watchers won't get restarted in the same second when a persistent connection failure occurred.

I've checked implementation from retrying library and it seems pretty similar to this one, so I'd rather stick with it, just reducing MAX_ATTEMPTS to 10.

Alright, I've just put 60 seconds there, I see no scenario when we want to wait longer. And we reach 60 seconds only on 5th retry, meaning that API was down for around 39 seconds already, which seems reasonable.

I see.

As for adding some randomness, I guess current implementation can breake contract of exponential backoff. Maybe something like this could be considered as a solution, so we make sure, the sleep is long enough for each attempt, yet it provides an amount of randomness:

  backoff = random.randint(2 ** (attempt - 1), 2 ** attempt -1) * interval

With DEFAULT_INTERNAL=3 and MAX_ATTEMPTS=10, that would gives max 51 minutes and 9 seconds, if my math is right, so my question remains, how long do we plan to wait before making another attempt? My wild guess would be tens of seconds, not minutes, but I might be wrong.

Hm, true, I'm using [kubernetes]watch_retry_timeout as a max_backoff value, which defaults to 60 seconds, but I see we recommend even setting it to an hour. That's way too long. Okay, let me revisit this.
should this be == 0 only? probably this is not call when quota is -1, but just in case. Quota -1 means infinite quota

Well, if quota is -1, then availability will end up as wrong result anyway and this is always checked with `has_limit()`, so it doesn't matter. But very good catch, this could be reworked a bit in a follow up patch.

This is an external resource. How is this external resource handled in Tacker during VNF package uploading?
Also, how is it handled during fetching this resource?

The vnf_artifacts DB table is also updated for an external resource where its artifact_path field is URI of ``Source``. The external resource file is not stored in Tacker and it should be downloaded at vnflcm operations.

When fetching, an external resource cannot be downloaded because you can download it directly form the URI and the path for the artifacts is not defined in the fetching URI of {artifactPath}.

Exactly, the images for VNFC are not inclueded in "additionalArtifacts". I added a note to describe it.
Can this API fetch images for VNFC?
No. The artifacts in vnf_artifacts DB table are fetched with this API. The images for VNFC are not included in vnf_artifacts.

I think it's a matter of flow control. Sharder marks a range deleted after it's shrunk so it knows to delete the DB later. Root should never go deleting itself, so... leave it.

Another way of thinking about it: If an object update lands, what should happen? With a deleted (sharded) shard, it needs to go find the container it *should* be in and move it as a misplaced object. At the end of the day, it should stay deleted. With a deleted root, we should pop back into existence.

neutron_lib/constants.py.message:
This is used here:

https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/agent/linux/keepalived.py#L193

And in the logic the /32 seems to matter. That's why I did not touch it, despite the near duplication.
This seems to be required for "bind" calls done by haproxy code, so I think is fine.  I think the /32 in METADATA_CIDR messes things up perhaps?

IMO this is wrong. Metadata uses only a single IP and accesses to that IP are being redirected on the router or on the DHCP agent. None of the other addresses in 169.254.0.0/16 are being used in the metadata service, instances don't need any IP in that net in order to access metadata.

So this is being used for configuring a metadata subnet, it's actually not an address.  And looking again at it the value seems wrong:

    '169.254.169.254/16'

Using netaddr that turns-into:

>>> netaddr.IPNetwork('169.254.169.254/16').network
IPAddress('169.254.0.0')

I think the ML2/OVS code in agent/linux/dhcp.py is using it correctly, I'm just not so sure of the OVN metadata agent code in ovn/metadata/agent.py is, it seems to calling:

$ ip addr add dev foo 169.254.169.254/16

I think in reality it should be using METADATA_CIDR as defined above.

Let me send out a "cleanup" patch for neutron and hopefully things will be clearer after that?
I haven't seen the cleanup patch, but METADATA_V4_CIDR should be the same as METADATA_CIDR, see above.

This is correct, though. For IPv6 access happens within the link-local network, which is fe80::/64, instances have their own link-local address and there is a "normal" connection setup happening within that directly connected link-local network.
That also sounds redundant, adding a route to an IPv4 address should implicitly have the "/32" added.
After seeing that Brian had to fix problems around this, I believe it's better to be explicit here. That's why I also took these comments from his patch.

I still don't see why the /16 should be used anywhere at all, but I see that it is being used in the DHCP agent code, I need to look into that in more detail in order to understand what is happening there.
Move this behind METADATA_PORT in order to avoid the ambiguity of whether the latter is also affected by the comment?

I don't think how many times going thru the loop should be compared with the build_interval in seconds. Code more readable if you compared the accumulated time so far to the total time allowed such as:

accumulated_time = cls.build_interval
while accumulated_time < cls.build_timeout
    ....
    accumulated_time += cls.build_interval

I suggest either use total loop count allowed or build_timeout allowed, but not to mix loop count with time allowed.

Bahh, I read the old version of the cpu-topologies document (I blame google).

If there is cpu_shared_set configured then I agree that hw:emulator_threads_policy=shared is enough as there will be a place to put the emulator thread without affecting the realtime instance. And I agree that without cpu_shared_set this is problematic. As a first thought I can imagine that the compute reports a trait if it supports full realtime instances (i.e. the trait is added if there is shared_cpu_set is configured to a non-empty set) but I see how complex it makes this. So don't insist.
